department.ch: 工業管理研究所碩士班

goal.en:
"In this course, we plan to use about the one third classes to talk about data collection and preparation, which includes sample selection, cleaning and transformation, and the rest two third classes to discuss methodologies of data analysis, which includes multivariate models and data mining techniques. The data analysis lectures will focus on applications instead of theoretical introductions. Part of the learning will be carried out by the usage of the statistical software and data mining software, such as Minitab and SPSS Clementine.
This course will be proceeded in a mixture of 50% lectures, 30% discussions, and 20% students presentations. Each topic will be introduced and discussed for one or two weekly meetings. Students are required to form groups, and each group should select one interesting problem to be the team project. The purpose of doing project is to apply the models we have learned in class to address real-life issues.
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be well knowledgeable about some common multivariate models and data mining techniques, and should be able to perform basic data analysis with the aid of computer software.
Your ROLE in the Course:
Project. We will have a project in a group of Three students. Each group needs to choose and work on a specific subject. One presentation and one final report must be submitted for the group.
Class Participation. Class participation is crucial for learning the course content and for keeping in pace with the class progress.
1) You should be prepared for each class and should try to contribute to class discussions. Active and cooperative learning will be encouraged. During the lecture, you are expected to answer/raise questions, and participate in small-group activities such as modeling and solving problems, and interpreting solutions.
2) Attendance will be taken in classes and will constitute part of your participation grade.
Assignments. You will apply the concepts learnt in class to a variety of problems. The assignments will be given to students in the end of each topic. Homework assignments must be prepared in a group of Two students.
1) All assignments should be prepared professionally. Every assignment must include your name and student ID number. Unorganized, illegible, or incomplete assignments will not be graded.
2) Late assignments will not be accepted. Photocopied homework solutions will not be accepted.
3) TAs will provide helps in the use of software.
Examinations. The final exam will be administered as scheduled by the school. Examinations will be closed book and notes.
1) Each student will be allowed a A4 sheet of handwritten “crib” notes for the exams. No photocopies or computer printouts will be allowed.
2) No make-up exams will be given unless required by National Central University policies. Students who are eligible for a make-up exam or need extra time must contact the instructor at least one week prior to the exam date.
3) Cheating in any form will not be tolerated. Any student caught cheating will be censured in full accordance with National Central University policies."
goal.ch: "In this course, we plan to use about the one third classes to talk about data collection and preparation, which includes sample selection, cleaning and transformation, and the rest two third classes to discuss methodologies of data analysis, which includes multivariate models and data mining techniques. The data analysis lectures will focus on applications instead of theoretical introductions. Part of the learning will be carried out by the usage of the statistical software and data mining software, such as Minitab and SAS EG and SAS EM. This course will be proceeded in a mixture of 50% lectures, 30% discussions, and 20% students presentations. Each topic will be introduced and discussed for one or two weekly meetings. Students are required to form groups, and each group should select one interesting problem to be the team project. The purpose of doing project is to apply the models we have learned in class to address real-life issues. Upon completion of this course, students are expected to be well knowledgeable about some common multivariate models and data mining techniques, and should be able to perform basic data analysis with the aid of computer software."

content.en:
"Week 1: Course Introduction/SAS Software Installation
Week 2: Software Demonstration (SAS EG and SAS EM)
Week 3: Data Collection, Sampling Methods, Data Preparation, Data Partition
Week 4: Linear Regression
Week 5: Logistic Regression
Week 6: Neural Networks
Week 7: Discriminant Analysis
Week 8: Decision Trees and Regression Trees
Week 9: Model Evaluation
Week 10: Problem Discussion
Week 11: Clustering
Week 12: Association Rules
Week 13: Principal Component Analysis
Week 14: Factor Analysis
Week 15: Bayesian Classification
Week 16: Project Presentations I
Week 17: Project Presentations II
Week 18: Final Exam"
